0: NORTH ATTLEBOROUGH, Mass. (AP) — A Massachusetts coffee shop owner says he received a cease-and-desist letter from Dunkin' Donuts claiming trademark infringement for riffing on the chain's catchphrase. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Steve Copoulos tells the Sun Chronicle (http://bit.ly/2slf5yU ) he added window art reading "North now runs on Mike's" on his Mike's Coffee shop in North Attleborough. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR While he expected a few laughs from customers, Copoulos says he was surprised to find the letter from the Canton, Massachusetts-based coffee shop chain claiming he was infringing on their "America Runs on Dunkin'" slogan and Copoulos' variation implied an affiliation. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Copoulos says he wants to be the "exact opposite" of a corporate coffee chain and has since erased the sign. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Dunkin' Donuts, in a statement, said it wrote the letter, "In support of our legal rights under trademark law and in support of our franchisees." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR ___ NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR This story has been changed to correct that Dunkin' Donuts is based in Canton, Massachusetts, not Quincy.
